SystemOutput:
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Mr. Brian is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for congestive heart failure and hypertension, who presents today for follow-up of his chronic problems. The patient reports feeling out of sorts lately, with fatigue, lightheadedness, and bloating. He has been experiencing these symptoms for about five weeks. He has been involved in home renovation projects and has had difficulty maintaining a healthy diet due to the construction in his kitchen. He denies fever, chills, and abdominal pain but endorses shortness of breath during exertion and slight chest cramps that resolve after about an hour.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Fatigue, lightheadedness
• Cardiovascular: Shortness of breath during exertion, slight chest cramps
• Respiratory: Slight cough
• Gastrointestinal: Bloating

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Vital Signs: Blood pressure, heart rate, and oxygenation within normal limits
• Neck: Jugular venous distention to about 8 centimeters
• Heart: 3/6 systolic ejection murmur
• Lungs: Fine crackles at the bases bilaterally
• Lower Extremities: 1+ pitting edema

RESULTS

Chest X-ray: Fluid in the lungs
Echocardiogram (4 months ago): Pumping function reduced at 45%, mitral regurgitation

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Congestive Heart Failure:
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient is retaining fluid, as evidenced by physical exam findings and chest x-ray.
   • Medical Treatment: Increase Lasix to 80 mg once a day. Patient to weigh themselves daily and call if weight gain or shortness of breath occurs. Order another echocardiogram.

2. Hypertension:
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient's blood pressure is well-managed at this time.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue Lisinopril 20 mg daily. Patient to continue recording blood pressures at home and report any elevations via the patient portal.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CC:

Right knee pain.

HPI:

Ms. Thompson is a 43-year-old female who presents today for an evaluation of right knee pain. She states she was changing a light bulb on a ladder and stumbled, twisting her knee while trying to catch her fall. The incident occurred yesterday. She has been applying ice and taking ibuprofen, but it does not seem to help. She denies any numbness or tingling in her leg. She has a history of atrial fibrillation and takes digoxin. She has a past surgical history of a nose job. She denies any allergies.

EXAM:

Examination of the right knee shows tenderness over the medial meniscus area. Pain is elicited with flexion and valgus stressing of the knee. Normal sensation in the lower extremity.

RESULTS:

X-rays of the right knee obtained on today's visit show no fractures or dislocations. There is a small amount of fluid present.

IMPRESSION:

Acute medial meniscus strain.

PLAN:

At this point, I discussed the diagnosis and treatment options with the patient. I have recommended we place her in a knee brace and provide crutches for temporary use. She will follow up in 1 week for re-evaluation, and if not improved, we will consider an MRI. I will prescribe Motrin 800 mg, to be taken every 6 hours with food, for a two-week supply.

All questions were answered.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Back pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Logan is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for diabetes type 2, hypertension, and osteoarthritis, who presents today with back pain.

The patient states he was helping his daughter with heavy equipment and lifted some boxes too quickly, which were too heavy. He heard a pop in his lower back and had to lie down for about an hour before the pain was relieved. The pain has been persistent since the incident, which occurred on Saturday morning. He has tried Tylenol, ibuprofen, and icy heat without significant relief. He experienced tingling in his right toes until Sunday afternoon.

Regarding his diabetes, the patient admits to having a sweet tooth and a less than ideal diet recently. He is taking his medication as prescribed.

Regarding his hypertension, the patient monitors his blood pressure readings at home during the week but tends to forget on weekends. He is taking his medication as prescribed.

Regarding his osteoarthritis, the patient experiences occasional aggravation in his knee but has been managing it well.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Musculoskeletal: Endorses lower back pain. Endorses tingling in right toes until Sunday afternoon.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Cardiovascular: Grade 2/6 systolic heart murmur, stable.
• Musculoskeletal: Pain to palpation of the lumbar spine. Pain with flexion and extension of the back. Negative straight leg raise.

Results:

Back X-ray, ordered and obtained in the office today, shows normal bony alignment and no fracture present.

Hemoglobin A1c is elevated at 8.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Logan is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for diabetes type 2, hypertension, and osteoarthritis, who presents today with back pain.

Lumbar strain.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient reports feeling a 'pop' and immediate pain while lifting heavy boxes. He has tried Tylenol and ibuprofen without significant relief.
• Medical Treatment: Initiate meloxicam 15 mg once daily. Continue icing the area and avoid strenuous activity. Refer to physical therapy for further management.

Diabetes type 2.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient has been compliant with medication, but his recent hemoglobin A1c was 8.
• Medical Treatment: Increase metformin to 1000 mg twice daily. Repeat hemoglobin A1c in 6 months.

Hypertension.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient's blood pressure readings have been running on the high side.
• Medical Treatment: Increase lisinopril from 10 mg to 20 mg daily.

Osteoarthritis.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient has been managing his knee pain well and no further workup is needed at this time.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow-up as needed.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Annual exam and follow-up of chronic problems.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Ralph is a 62-year-old male with a past medical history significant for depression, hypertension, and prior lobectomy. He presents for his annual exam. He reports a relatively stable mood with no recent depressive episodes and adherence to Prozac. He has been managing his hypertension with Norvasc but admits to occasional missed doses on weekends. He experiences shortness of breath with exertion during his morning runs, which are typically 4-5 miles long. He denies any other significant symptoms.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Ears, Nose, Mouth, and Throat: Nasal congestion due to pollen.
• Cardiovascular: Shortness of breath with exertion.
• Respiratory: No cough or wheezing.
• Musculoskeletal: No pain or swelling.
• Psychiatric: Depression managed with Prozac.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Neurological/Psychological: Appropriate mood and affect.
• Respiratory: Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
• Cardiovascular: Slight 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.
• Musculoskeletal: No lower extremity edema.

VITALS REVIEWED

• Blood Pressure: 120/80 mmHg.

RESULTS

Electrocardiogram: Normal.
Chest X-ray: Normal, no concerning findings related to prior lobectomy.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Depression.
   • Medical Reasoning: Stable mood, adherence to Prozac.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue Prozac 20 mg daily. Refill prescription.
   • Patient Education and Counseling: Encouraged to maintain current management strategies.

2. Hypertension.
   • Medical Reasoning: Blood pressure controlled, occasional missed doses on weekends.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue Norvasc as prescribed.
   • Additional Testing: Order an echocardiogram for the murmur.

3. Prior lobectomy.
   • Medical Reasoning: No significant respiratory symptoms, exercising regularly.
   • Medical Treatment: No further follow-up with the surgeon needed.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CC:

Right middle finger pain.

HPI:

Ms. Hill is a 41-year-old female who presents today for an evaluation of right middle finger pain after she was rear-ended in a motor vehicle accident 5 days ago. She has no other injuries.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS:

Digoxin

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:

Atrial Fibrillation

EXAM:

Examination of the right middle finger shows tenderness over the distal phalanx.

RESULTS:

X-rays of the right middle finger, 3 views obtained on today's visit shows a comminuted distal phalanx fracture.

IMPRESSION:

Right middle finger distal phalanx fracture.

PLAN:

At this point, I discussed the diagnosis and treatment options with the patient. I recommend a prescription for Tramadol 50 mg every 6 hours as needed for pain, dispense 8. She is provided a finger splint and will return in 2 weeks for a follow-up x-ray. All questions were answered.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Iron deficiency anemia and fatigue.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Christina Cooper, a 65-year-old female, presents with a long-standing history of iron deficiency anemia. She was recently unable to donate blood due to her anemia. The patient reports fatigue, shortness of breath, wheezing, headaches, chills, and worsening anxiety and depression. She has been anemic since the age of 13 and had a hysterectomy in 1996. Her last colonoscopy was approximately 5-6 years ago with normal results.

PAST HISTORY

Medical
Iron deficiency anemia.

Gynecologic History
Hysterectomy in 1996.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Alcohol consumption: Occasional, 1-2 times per year.

FAMILY HISTORY

Not mentioned.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS

Ferrous sulfate 25 mg tablets, twice daily.
Over-the-counter vitamin B12.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Cardiovascular: Normal heart sounds.
Respiratory: Clear lung sounds.
Abdomen: Soft, non-tender, no masses or organomegaly.

ASSESSMENT

Iron deficiency anemia and fatigue.

PLAN

1. Upper endoscopy and colonoscopy: Schedule these procedures to assess for potential sources of anemia or GI bleed. If inconclusive, consider capsule endoscopy.
2. Hematologist referral: Refer the patient to a hematologist for further evaluation and management of anemia.
3. Continue ferrous sulfate 25 mg tablets twice daily with orange juice for better absorption. Recheck CBC, iron, ferritin, B12, and folate in 8-12 weeks.

INSTRUCTIONS

Schedule appointments for upper endoscopy, colonoscopy, and hematologist. Follow bowel prep instructions provided. Call the clinic with any questions or worsening symptoms.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Worsening headaches and pituitary lesion.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Mr. Bruce Ward is a 52-year-old male who presents to the clinic today for consultation regarding a newly diagnosed pituitary lesion. He was referred by Dr. Henry Howard for possible surgical intervention. Mr. Ward initially presented to his primary care provider on 3/1/21 with complaints of worsening headaches over the past few months. He denies any history of headaches. His past clinical history is unremarkable.

Workup for worsening headaches was initiated with brain MRI and serology, where the pituitary lesion was incidentally discovered. Labs dated 3/3/21, including CBC, UNES, coagulation, and CRP, were all normal. Pituitary hormone profile demonstrates a low TSH, with all other results normal. MRI of the brain with contrast from 3/4/21 reveals a pituitary lesion with elevation and compression of the optic chiasm. The ventricles are normal in size, and no other abnormalities are noted.

PAST HISTORY

Medical
None.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Occupation: Computer programmer.
Marital status: Married for 25 years.
Recently purchased a small house.
Adopted, unknown family medical history.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS

None.

RESULTS

MRI brain with contrast: Pituitary lesion with elevation and compression of the optic chiasm.

ASSESSMENT

• Pituitary adenoma.

PLAN

1. Recommend surgical intervention for excision and decompression of the pituitary fossa due to symptomatic optic chiasmal compression.
2. Refer the patient to the eye doctor for a full exam and visual field test to assess peripheral vision before and after surgery.
3. Discuss the risks and benefits of the transsphenoidal approach for surgery with the patient.
4. Schedule surgery and visual field test with the surgery scheduler, Deborah.
5. Encourage the patient to call if they have any questions or concerns.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Chest pain and difficulty swallowing in October 2020.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Betty Hill is a 53 y.o. female who presents today for evaluation of chest pain and difficulty swallowing that occurred in October 2020. The patient reports that the chest pain lasted for four days and was located in the center of her chest, behind her breastbone. The pain was sharp and felt worse with eating. She also experienced difficulty swallowing during this time. The patient went to the ER, where they performed an EKG and blood tests, all of which were normal. The ER suspected a GI issue and referred her to our clinic. The patient's symptoms resolved approximately three days after her ER visit and have not recurred since.

PAST HISTORY

Medical
Uterine fibroids.
Anemia.
Gallbladder removal (several years ago).

SOCIAL HISTORY

The patient reports going through a stressful job transition around the time of her symptoms.

FAMILY HISTORY

No known family history of GI problems.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Negative for abdominal pain and bowel movement issues.
Positive for mild tenderness to light palpation in the upper abdominal quadrants.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Mild tenderness to light palpation in the upper abdominal quadrants. No other abnormalities noted.

ASSESSMENT

Possible etiologies for the patient's symptoms include GERD, dyspepsia, esophagitis, musculoskeletal issues, and anxiety. It is suspected that the patient may have experienced an anxiety attack related to her job transition, with possible contributions from musculoskeletal issues.

PLAN

1. Discussed the option of an EGD versus monitoring for symptoms. The patient elected to self-monitor her symptoms and will call with any recurrence or change.
2. The patient should follow up as needed for any other GI complaints.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Follow-up for Smith-Magenis Syndrome.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Katherine is a 22-month-old female who presents for follow-up. She was diagnosed with Smith-Magenis Syndrome by a neurologist due to her developmental delays. She has a twin sister who is developing normally. Katherine has a history of feeding difficulties and reflux, for which she sees a GI doctor. She is also followed by a dietician who recommended taking her off cow's milk. She has seen an allergist, orthopedic doctor, and ophthalmologist. She is currently in feeding therapy, occupational therapy, and physical therapy, with speech therapy scheduled to start soon.

The patient's geneticist mentioned that individuals with Smith-Magenis Syndrome may have kidney anomalies, and the patient is here for a kidney ultrasound to assess her kidney function.

PAST HISTORY

Medical
Smith-Magenis Syndrome.
Feeding difficulties.
Reflux.

FAMILY HISTORY

No family history of kidney failure, dialysis, or transplant.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS

Ripple pea protein milk.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Well-nourished female, slightly fussy when examined. Eyes are small appearing. Mild hypotonia of the lower extremities in her arms. Normal external female genitalia.

ASSESSMENT

Smith-Magenis Syndrome with possible congenital anomalies of the kidney and urinary tract.

PLAN

1. Obtain a kidney ultrasound today to screen for any abnormalities.
2. If there are abnormalities on the kidney ultrasound, determine next steps and future follow-up.
3. If the ultrasound is normal, no further follow-up with nephrology is needed.
4. Continue with current therapies and follow-up with other specialists as needed.

INSTRUCTIONS

Complete kidney ultrasound today. The nurse will provide paperwork and instructions for the ultrasound. The doctor will call with the results and discuss any necessary next steps.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right wrist pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Diana, a 35-year-old female, presents to the clinic today for evaluation of right wrist pain. The onset of her pain began when she slipped on the stairs while doing laundry and tried to catch herself with her right arm. She reports that her wrist started to hurt severely and became swollen. The patient rates her pain level as a 9 out of 10. She has been icing her wrist, using an ace wrap, and taking ibuprofen, which provided minimal relief. The injury occurred yesterday morning.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Positive right wrist pain.
Skin: Positive swelling and bruising in the right wrist.
Neurological: Reports slight tingling in fingers.

VITALS

BP: 140/70
HR: 80 bpm
Temp: 97.2°F
RR: 20 bpm

PHYSICAL EXAM

CV: Capillary refill is normal. No edema in lower legs.
NEURO: Normal sensation in fingers. Slight tingling reported.
MSK: Examination of the right wrist reveals obvious swelling, ecchymosis, and tenderness on palpation. Pain on flexion, extension, radial deviation, and ulnar deviation. Limited ability to make a tight fist. Bony crepitus present.

RESULTS

X-ray of the right wrist reveals a Colles' fracture.

ASSESSMENT

Colles' fracture of the right wrist.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, I have had a lengthy discussion with the patient regarding her current symptoms. I have explained to her that her symptoms are consistent with a Colles' fracture. I have recommended conservative treatment initially, including a brace for her right wrist. We will schedule surgery as soon as possible to repair the fracture. In the meantime, I will prescribe 50 mg of Ultram every six hours for pain management. I will also recommend physical therapy for the patient, starting a few weeks after surgery. The patient will be advised to wear the brace for six weeks post-surgery. A follow-up appointment will be scheduled in a month to assess her progress and discuss her upcoming vacation plans.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient is advised to contact the office if her pain worsens or if she experiences any complications following surgery.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right knee pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Patient reports slipping and falling while working on his property a week ago. He felt a pop in his knee and has been experiencing pain and swelling since the incident.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Hypertension, managed with 20 mg Lisinopril.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient admits to struggling with maintaining a low-sodium diet.

VITALS

Blood pressure: 150/70 mmHg

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Denies fever, chest pain, and shortness of breath.
Musculoskeletal: Reports right knee pain and swelling.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Respiratory
- Assessment of Respiratory Effort: Normal respiratory effort. Lungs clear bilaterally.

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: Grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.

Musculoskeletal
- Right knee: Pain to palpation of the medial aspect. Pain with flexion and extension. Edema and effusion present.

RESULTS

X-rays of the right knee were obtained and reviewed in office today. These reveal no fractures or bony abnormalities.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Right knee MCL strain.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient's history of fall and physical exam findings suggest a medial collateral ligament strain.
- Medical Treatment: Prescribe ibuprofen 800 mg twice daily for pain and swelling. Provide a knee brace for support and recommend icing the knee for 20 minutes, 3-4 times daily. Advise patient to elevate and rest the leg.

2. Hypertension.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient's blood pressure remains elevated despite taking Lisinopril 20 mg.
- Medical Treatment: Continue Lisinopril 20 mg. Refer patient to nutrition counseling to improve diet and sodium intake.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up as needed.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Left shoulder pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Wayne is a pleasant middle-aged male who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of left shoulder pain. The onset of his pain began 3 weeks ago, without any improvement. He denies any specific injury; however, he has been renovating his basement and putting in a new ceiling. He does not recall hitting or falling onto the left shoulder. The patient states he is very active and has experienced left shoulder pain before that usually resolves with Tylenol.

The patient reports significant pain with reaching, lifting, and overhead activities. The pain is constant. He states the pain is primarily located in the left shoulder and denies it radiates down into the left arm. The patient also reports difficulty sleeping secondary to the pain. He has been taking Tylenol for pain, which provides partial relief. He denies any numbness or tingling in his left arm or fingers. The patient denies he has done any physical therapy.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports left shoulder pain. Neurological: Denies numbness or tingling.

VITALS

All vital signs are within the normal limits.

PHYSICAL EXAM

MSK: Examination of the left shoulder: Limited active and passive ROM. Tenderness over the greater tuberosity of the humerus. No tenderness at the sternoclavicular or AC joints. Good hand grip. Neurovascularly intact distally. Capillary refill is less than 3 seconds. Sensation is intact to light touch distally.

RESULTS

X-rays of the left shoulder were obtained and reviewed today. These are normal and reveal no fracture or bony abnormalities.

ASSESSMENT

Left shoulder pain, likely rotator cuff tendinopathy.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, I have had a lengthy discussion with him regarding his current symptoms. I have explained that his x-rays did not reveal any signs of a fracture. I have recommended that we obtain an MRI of the left shoulder to evaluate for possible rotator cuff tendinopathy. The patient was provided with a referral to formal physical therapy. He will engage in a 6-to-8-week course in order to strengthen his left shoulder. I have also advised him to take Tylenol as needed for pain. If his symptoms do not improve, we may consider a steroid injection to the left shoulder.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up with me once the MRI results are available for review and further discussion.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Left knee pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Andrea is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of left knee pain. The pain occurs occasionally, less than once a day, and is described as the whole kneecap feeling unstable. The pain comes and goes quickly and does not last long. The patient denies any history of injury to the knee and has not taken any medications for the pain. The knee pain has not significantly interfered with her daily activities, but she is concerned about an upcoming trip where she will be doing a lot of walking and line dancing.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Hypertension, diabetes mellitus.

MEDICATIONS

Farxiga, amlodipine, lisinopril, hydrochlorothiazide, metformin.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Vital signs: Temperature 98.2 F, pulse 72, respirations 16, blood pressure 122/70.
Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, 2/6 systolic ejection murmur at the left base.
Pulmonary: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally.
Musculoskeletal: Left knee exam - no ecchymosis, edema, effusion, or pain to palpation. Full range of motion, negative varus and valgus test.

RESULTS

Left knee x-ray: No evidence of fracture or bony abnormality.

ASSESSMENT

1. Left knee pain - likely arthritis.
2. Hypertension.
3. Diabetes mellitus.

PLAN

1. For the left knee pain, prescribe meloxicam 15 mg daily and consider physical therapy to strengthen the muscles around the knee.
2. Continue lisinopril 20 mg daily for hypertension and order an echocardiogram to evaluate the heart murmur.
3. Order hemoglobin A1c and lipid panel to assess diabetes management and make any necessary adjustments to metformin dosage.

The patient will be scheduled for an echocardiogram, and the nurse will assist with setting up the appointment.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Sore throat and cough.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient has a history of hypertension and diabetes. Recently diagnosed with stage three nonsmall cell lung cancer.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient reports good support from family, friends, and nursing staff.

MEDICATIONS

Patient is currently on cisplatin and etoposide for chemotherapy.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Reports fatigue.
HENT: Reports sore throat and dry cough.
Respiratory: Denies shortness of breath.

VITALS

Oxygen saturation: Within normal limits.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Head and Face
- Examination: No pain to palpation of the frontal or maxillary sinuses.

Ears, Nose, Mouth, and Throat
- Examination of Throat: No cervical lymphadenopathy or supraclavicular adenopathy.

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: Regular rate and rhythm. No murmurs.

Respiratory
- Auscultation of Lungs: Crackles bilaterally.

Skin
- Examination of Chest: Erythema on the anterior side of the chest on the left side.

Lower Extremities
- Examination: No edema.

RESULTS

Chest X-ray: Mild radiation pneumonitis.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Lung cancer.
- Medical Treatment: Continue with the current chemotherapy regimen of cisplatin and etoposide and current dose of radiation at 45 Gy. Repeat imaging after completion to assess tumor size for possible surgical removal.

2. Radiation pneumonitis.
- Medical Treatment: Prescribe low-dose prednisone (40 mg daily for 5 days) to reduce inflammation.

3. Painful swallowing.
- Medical Treatment: Prescribe lidocaine swish and swallow to be used four times a day to help with swallowing and prevent dehydration and weight loss.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Low immunoglobulin A (IgA) level.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient reports frequent colds during winter, which tend to linger. Patient's family owns a donut shop. Patient denies any family history of immune deficiencies.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Type 2 diabetes, recently started on metformin.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: No fever.
Respiratory: No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
Gastrointestinal: No abdominal infections or diarrhea.

VITALS

All vitals within normal range.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs.
Respiratory: Lungs clear.
Neck: No lymphadenopathy.
Abdominal: Soft, non-tender.

LAB RESULTS

Recent lab work consistent with IgA deficiency.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. IgA deficiency.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient's lab work shows low IgA levels, which is a common immunodeficiency. Most people with this deficiency live normal lives without complications. Some may experience frequent respiratory, sinus, or abdominal infections, but this does not seem to be the case for the patient.
- Patient Education and Counseling: The nature of the diagnosis was discussed with the patient. I explained that IgA deficiency is common and usually not a cause for concern. However, the patient should watch for infections that do not resolve or any changes in their abdominal tract. If they require blood products, they should inform the provider of their IgA deficiency.
- Medical Treatment: Additional blood work will be ordered to check other antibodies. No other treatment is necessary at this time.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right elbow pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Lawrence is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of right elbow pain. The patient has been experiencing right elbow pain for approximately 4 days. The pain is localized to the medial aspect of his elbow and can radiate down into his forearm. He denies any trauma or previous injury to the right elbow. The patient has been engaging in pottery activities during the pandemic, which he believes may have contributed to the pain. He rates the pain as a 6/10 and reports that it interferes with his daily activities and sleep. He has tried ibuprofen for pain relief with minimal success.

SOCIAL HISTORY

The patient has been engaging in pottery activities during the pandemic.

MEDICATIONS

The patient reports taking ibuprofen for pain relief.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports right elbow pain.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Vitals: Within normal limits.
MSK:
Examination of the right elbow: Pain to palpation along the medial aspect. Pain with pronation of the forearm. Pain with resistance against flexion of the left wrist.

RESULTS

X-ray images of the right elbow were obtained and reviewed in the office today. These reveal no evidence of fracture or bony abnormality.

ASSESSMENT

Right medial epicondylitis.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, we discussed the diagnosis of medial epicondylitis. The patient is advised to rest the affected elbow and will be provided with a sling to wear while awake. He is instructed to apply ice to the elbow for 20 minutes three times a day and take ibuprofen 600 mg every 6 hours with food for a full week. The patient is advised to refrain from pottery activities for the next couple of weeks. A follow-up appointment is scheduled for one week to assess the patient's progress.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Emergency department follow up.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient reports history of hypertension and recent hospitalization for congestive heart failure.

MEDICATIONS

Patient reports taking Bumex 2 mg once daily, Cozaar 100 mg daily, and Norvasc 5 mg once daily.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Denies sleep disturbance.
Cardiovascular: Reports occasional chest pain, thought to be heartburn.
Respiratory: Reports shortness of breath during physical activity.
Genitourinary: No issues reported.

VITALS

Blood Pressure: 128/72 mmHg
Temperature: 98.7 degrees F
Heart Rate: 72 bpm
Oxygen Saturation: 96%

PHYSICAL EXAM

Neck
- General Examination: No jugular venous distention.

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: Stable 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.

Musculoskeletal
- Examination: Trace lower extremity edema.

RESULTS

Echocardiogram reveals a preserved ejection fraction of 55%, normal diastolic filling, and mild-to-moderate mitral regurgitation.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Congestive heart failure.
- Medical Reasoning: This appears to have been caused by dietary indiscretion and uncontrolled hypertension.
- Patient Education and Counseling: I encouraged the patient to continue making dietary modifications, including limiting sodium intake. Referral placed for consult with a nutritionist for education and recommendations regarding diet.
- Medical Treatment: Continue with Bumex 2 mg once daily. Patient advised to weigh themselves daily and call if they gain 3 pounds in 2 days.

2. Hypertension.
- Medical Reasoning: This has been poorly controlled due to inconsistent compliance with medication and dietary indiscretion.
- Patient Education and Counseling: We discussed the importance of taking medications consistently and making dietary modifications.
- Medical Treatment: Continue on Cozaar 100 mg daily and Norvasc 5 mg once daily. Renal artery ultrasound ordered to rule out any issues such as renal artery stenosis.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up in 3 months.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Kidney stones.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Russell is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of kidney stones. The patient was referred from his primary care physician. The onset of his pain began several days ago, with sharp pain on the right side of his abdomen below his ribs. The pain radiates to his lower abdomen and into his groin. The pain is intermittent and severe when it occurs. The patient reports a burning sensation during urination and darker urine at times. He has taken Tylenol for pain relief, but it has not been effective. The patient has a history of kidney stones and has been able to pass them in the past. His father also had kidney stones.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Gastrointestinal: Reports nausea but no vomiting.
Genitourinary: Reports burning sensation during urination and darker urine at times.

VITALS

Not provided.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Abdomen: No tenderness to palpation, no rebound or guarding, no peritoneal signs. Positive CVA tenderness on the right flank.

RESULTS

The CT scan of the abdomen revealed a 0.5 cm kidney stone located in the proximal right ureter. There is no evidence of hydronephrosis.

ASSESSMENT

Right kidney stone.

PLAN

We reviewed the patient's CT results in detail today. I have recommended that we treat the patient conservatively. I have prescribed the patient oxycodone 5 mg every 6 to 8 hours for pain. He may continue to take Tylenol between the oxycodone doses for any breakthrough pain. The patient should push fluids to help facilitate urination and passing the stone. I have provided a strainer for the patient to use when he urinates until the stone passes. I have also recommended that we obtain a BMP, urinalysis, and urine culture to evaluate for any signs of infection.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up with me in 1 to 2 weeks to check on his progress. If his symptoms have not improved, we will discuss further treatment options including lithotripsy or ureteroscopy. The patient should contact me if he experiences worsening symptoms.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Non-healing right foot ulcer.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Nicholas is a 79-year-old male who presents today for evaluation of a non-healing right foot ulcer. He reports having the ulcer for approximately six weeks, which started as a blister after wearing tight shoes. The blister has since unroofed, revealing thick, soft, and mushy skin with a foul smell and yellow drainage. He has been on antibiotics for six days, with some initial improvement, but now reports the wound has turned black around the edges and he is experiencing calf cramping. He also notes a red streak extending up his calf and increased warmth in the area. He has a history of well-controlled diabetes with a recent A1C of 6.7, but his blood sugars have been trending higher in the past few weeks.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient reports a history of diabetes and diabetic neuropathy.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient enjoys hiking and recently tried a new pair of diabetic shoes.

MEDICATIONS

Patient is currently on antibiotics for the foot ulcer.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Reports fever of 99.7 and chills.
Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain.
Respiratory: Reports cough and shortness of breath.
Skin: Reports non-healing right foot ulcer.
Neurological: Denies headaches or numbness/tingling in extremities.

VITALS

Slight fever.
Blood pressure and heart rate within normal limits.

PHYSICAL EXAM

CV: Normal heart sounds.
RESPIRATORY: Clear to auscultation bilaterally.
NECK: No jugular venous distention or carotid bruits.
MSK: Examination of the right foot reveals a 2 x 2 cm necrotic wound on the heel with sloughing tissue, cellulitis, and erythemia. No bony exposure. Bilateral palpable femoral and popliteal pulses, but non-palpable dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses (present via Doppler). No pain on palpation of the wound.

ASSESSMENT

1. Non-healing diabetic foot ulcer, right foot
2. Diabetes
3. Possible cellulitis

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination findings today, I have had a lengthy discussion with the patient in regards to his current symptoms. We discussed that his right foot ulcer is concerning and will require further evaluation and treatment. I will order a test to check blood supply for this wound. I will perform a debridement today in the office and obtain a culture to guide antibiotic therapy. We will continue the current antibiotics and reevaluate based on culture results. I want the patient to follow up with his endocrinologist to ensure continued control of his diabetes. I will see the patient again in seven days to monitor his progress.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Tick bite on right knee.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Patient reports spending time outdoors, including hunting and yard work. He noticed a tick bite on his right knee over a week ago, which has been causing burning and discomfort. He has not experienced fever or chills, but reports feeling generally unwell and having a headache since the tick bite.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Hypertension, Diabetes

MEDICATIONS

Lisinopril 20 mg daily, Metformin 1000 mg twice daily

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Denies fever, chills, or body aches.
Musculoskeletal: Reports arthritic pain, but no new joint pain since tick bite.

VITALS

Blood pressure: 122/70 mmHg
Heart rate: 67 bpm
Temperature: 98.4 F

PHYSICAL EXAM

Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm. No murmurs, gallops, or rubs.
Respiratory: Clear to auscultation bilaterally.
Musculoskeletal: Full range of motion in right knee. Pain to palpation over right anterior knee. Erythema, edema, and area of fluctuance over right patella. Bull's-eye rash present over right knee.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Suspected Lyme disease due to tick bite and bull's-eye rash.
   - Medical Treatment: Start Doxycycline 100 mg twice daily for 3 weeks.
   - Diagnostic Testing: Order Lyme titer and Western blot to confirm diagnosis.

2. Hypertension
   - Continue Lisinopril 20 mg daily.
   - Order lipid panel to assess cholesterol levels.

3. Diabetes
   - Continue Metformin 1000 mg twice daily.
   - Order hemoglobin A1C to assess long-term blood sugar control.
   - Order basic metabolic panel to monitor kidney function.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up as needed or if symptoms worsen.
